intro: Deyeuxia erythrostachya var. neuquenensis, commonly known as the Neuquén sedge, is a perennial grass species native to South America, particularly Argentina. It is characterized by its slender, grass-like stems and narrow, linear leaves. The plant typically grows in wetland or marshy environments, where it thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Its inflorescence consists of a dense cluster of spikelets, which are often reddish in color, giving it its species name. This variety is of interest in ecological studies due to its role in stabilizing wetland ecosystems.
